repnme.cdata!: Poland - Hard Coal Mine Closure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The implementation completion report on
            a loan to the Republic of Poland for a Hard Coal Mine
            Closure Project, the overall outcome rating of the project
            is moderately satisfactory, Bank performance was rated as
            satisfactory, Quality of supervision was rated satisfactory,
            and also borrowers' performance rated moderately
            satisfactory. The most important lessons learnt from this
            operation show that successful change does not come easily.
            Clearly, progress with respect to privatization has moved
            slower than what was originally envisaged. One of the
            reasons given to the World Bank Coal Team is the general
            negative opinion that the public has regarding privatization
            of other industries: like steel and shipyards. There is
            concern over potential job losses and the transfer of
            profits outside of the country. It seems apparent to the
            World Bank Coal Team that so far there has not been a fully
            adequate explanation to the mining companies workers of the
            potential benefits of privatization to them. Both Spolka
            Restrukturyzacji Kopaln S.A. (Mine Restructuring Company)
            (SRK) and Bytomska Spolka Restrukturyzacji Kopaln Sp. z o.o.
            (BSRK) underlined that the beginning of the Projects
            implementation has been a challenge for them since they were
            not familiar with the World Banks procurement procedures,
            however thanks to the regular trainings organized by the
            Banks staff and frequent updates of the Operations Manual,
            these procedures were eventually internalized. The
            implication is that the use of Sector Wide Approach (SWAps)
            may be most effective where differences in Banks procurement
            and national procurement procedures are minimal, easily
            resolved and conveyed to implementing agencies prior to
            implementation, in cases where country systems are
            undeveloped or inadequate and full harmonization of
            procedures is not possible.

docna.cdata!: Poland - Hard Coal Mine Closure Project

5171367.trustfund:
TF051898-PHRD-POLAND: COAL SECAL 3 -
            SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL MITIGATION OF COAL
5171367.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!: Poland - Hard Coal Mine Closure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
A major pillar of the 2002 Country
            Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Poland, is to enhance private
            sector-led growth, and employment creation through
            enterprise restructuring, and, support for coal sector
            reform was included as a priority within that pillar in the
            CAS. The Hard Coal Mine Closure Project will directly
            support the physical closure, and environmental reclamation
            of excess coal mine capacity from CY 2004-2006. It envisages
            main economic and social objectives, that improve
            profitability, and the financial liquidity of the sector,
            i.e., allows regular payments of its liabilities, including
            payments of environmental fees, and, mitigates the social
            consequences of the program's implementation. The
            objectives are to be achieved through reform, in the areas
            of industry structure, mine closure, employment and
            financial restructuring, and, privatization. Through its
            five components the project will, first, liquidate
            underground workings and shafts, remove equipment, and
            secure underground areas. This will entail closure of
            underground roadways through dams, and if necessary,
            dewatering should prevent water hazards to neighboring
            operating mines, keeping the underground partly functional.
            Following liquidation, demolition and clearing surface
            structures will take place. Activities include shafts
            liquidation, by isolating materials such as clay, closing
            with a cement cap; demolition of existing buildings, or, if
            possible, for sale option; dismantling of installations,
            structures, and equipment; stabilization of waste dumps,
            and, closure of tailings ponds. Preparation of a
            comprehensive dewatering master plan, environmental
            management plans, and mine closure plans, including
            engineering design studies and supporting documentation will
            be conducted. Land reclamation will be implemented in two
            phases: a) preparation of land for industrial activity,
            which will include clean up and ground leveling, and, b)
            preparation of land for recreational purposes, to include
            remediation actions, such as vegetation propagation.
            Finally, following the mine closure, monitoring and
            maintenance will take place, particularly emphasizing
            dewatering activities, as needed.

4130913.trustfund:
TF051898-PHRD-POLAND: COAL SECAL 3 -
            SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL MITIGATION OF COAL

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Hard Coal Mine Closure Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Hard Coal Mine Closure Project
            entails the mine closure process, conducted in accordance
            with Polish legislation, and in compliance with the European
            Union legislation. It is required to ensure participation of
            the society in the process regarding environmental impacts
            leading to the environmental assessment, and, to disseminate
            information on mines closures to local communities and
            nongovernmental organizations. To this end, the environment
            management framework (v. 1) stipulates the following
            mitigation measures. A waste management plan shall be in
            place for appropriate disposal of wastes generated by the
            debris from building structures, machine, and equipment.
            Particular attention will be given to the final waste
            disposal of dangerous materials, i.e., asbestos, oils and
            lubricants, and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), to comply
            with international standard regulation. Contractors will be
            responsible of waste collection, transportation, and
            disposal, through a binding precautionary clause contained
            in the bid documents, in strict compliance with
            environmental regulations. In addition, contractors will
            also be responsible for the use of new technologies that
            ensure minimum noise and dust emissions, as well as
            appropriate casings or protective barriers, and spraying
            surfaces regularly. Strict compliance requirements will be
            applied to contractors responsible for structures
            demolition, particularly if containing asbestos. However,
            the mine company itself shall undertake periodical
            maintenance and reviews of de-watering equipment, performed
            under strict supervision by its environmental protection
            services. Additionally, chemical and laboratory tests of
            underground water will be outsourced, focusing on the
            contents of chlorides and sulphates in discharges waters,
            including properties such as suspended matter, dissolved
            substances, etc. Other volumes address specifically the
            liquidation process of the Zaklad Gorniczy coal mine (V. 2)
            and the Katowice Kleofas mine (V. 3) environmental
            management plans.

docna.cdata!:
Environmental management framework for mines
            to be closed

display_title.display_title:
Poland - Hard Coal Mine Closure
            Project : environmental assessment (Vol. 4) : Environmental
            management framework for mines to be closed
